leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 42] s 42 Application for rehearing (cf Act No 43 1983, section 18)

leg:heading.title: Application for rehearing (cf Act No 43 1983, section 18)

p.text: A person aggrieved by an award may apply to the referring court for a rehearing of the proceedings concerned.
The application may (but need not) request that the rehearing be a full rehearing or limited rehearing.
The award is suspended from the time the application is made until an order for rehearing is made.

The section does not explicitly limit the time within which an application for rehearing must be made. CPA s 43 obliges the court to order a rehearing if the application is made “before the award takes effect”. This expression appears to refer to the date the award takes effect as a judgment. Unless the award is entered as a consent judgment, it cannot operate as a judgment until 28 days after it has been sent to the parties by the court registrar. In practical terms, therefore, the parties have at least 28 days in which to apply for a rehearing. And if the application is made within that time the court must order a rehearing if the amount claimed exceeds the relevant jurisdictional limit in the small claims division of the Local Court: see CPA s 43(1) .

It is unclear whether the same mandatory result would follow if the rehearing application was made after the 28 day period had expired but before the judgment was entered. On the one hand, the 28 day period seems incapable of extension because, unlike the position under the previous legislation, it is a statutory, rather than a rule based, period: see El Ali v GIO (NSW) (1988) 15 NSWLR 303 (extension of time permissible under a provision equivalent to r 1.11 ). On the other hand, because the award is taken to be a judgment of the court (CPA s 40(1) ) it must be entered ( r 36.12 ) and although it would ordinarily take effect when the order or judgment was “given or made”: r 36.4 ; it is difficult to apply this expression literally to an award which only operates as a judgment by virtue of CPA s 40 . Accordingly, it may be arguable that the award does not relevantly take effect until it has been entered as a judgment.

Whether or not the court would be obliged to order a rehearing in response to an application made more than 28 days after service to the award, the combined effect of ss 42(1) and 43(1) is to imply a discretion to grant the application. This flows from the absence of an explicit time restriction in s 42 , the mandatory entitlement to rehearing conferred by s 43(1) , and the fact that the award finality provided by CPA s 40 is expressed to be subject to CPA ss 42–47 . It would be contrary to established principles of statutory interpretation to regard the entitlement to apply for a rehearing conferred by s 42(1) as subject to a time limit where none is clearly expressed: Oshlack v Richmond River Council (1998) 193 CLR 72 at [21]; 152 ALR 83 ; FAI General Insurance Co Ltd v Southern Cross Exploration NL (1988) 165 CLR 268 at 283–4, 290; 77 ALR 411; BC8802594 ; Emanuele v Australian Securities Commission (1997) 188 CLR 114 at 136–7; 144 ALR 359 . And in the light of that consideration the mandatory obligation in s 43(1) would not ordinarily be construed as concluding the courts’ powers to deal with an application otherwise permitted by CPA s 42(1) . For these reasons, it is reasonable to suppose that the discretionary considerations relevant to any application for an extension of time would also be relevant in the determination of a rehearing application made after the 28 day period provided for in CPA s 40 : see the notes accompanying UCPR r 1.12 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 43] s 43 Order for rehearing (cf Act No 43 1983, section 18A)

leg:heading.title: Order for rehearing (cf Act No 43 1983, section 18A)

p.text: The referring court must order a rehearing of proceedings the subject of an award if an application for rehearing is made before the award takes effect.

An order for rehearing may not be made unless the amount claimed in the proceedings, or the value of the property to which the proceedings relate, exceeds the jurisdictional limit of the Local Court when sitting in its Small Claims Division.
[subs (2) am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
An order for rehearing need not be made if it appears to the court that the applicant failed to attend a hearing before an arbitrator without good reason.

In an order for rehearing, the referring court may direct that the rehearing be a full rehearing or a limited rehearing, as the court thinks appropriate, and may do so regardless of whether the applicant requested a full rehearing or a limited rehearing or made no such request.
In the absence of a direction under subsection (4), the rehearing is to be a full rehearing.

An order for a limited rehearing must specify the aspects that are to be the subject of the rehearing, whether by reference to specific issues in dispute, specific parties to the dispute or otherwise.
The referring court may amend an order for rehearing at any time before or during a rehearing.

level.toc-caption: [s 43.5] Effect of change in jurisdictional limit

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 43.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 43(2).

heading.title: Effect of change in jurisdictional limit

p.text: The decision in Csalar v Circosta (2002) 55 NSWLR 212; [2002] NSWSC 482; BC200202888 is authority for the proposition that prohibition on rehearing in CPA s 43(2) operates by reference to the current Local Court jurisdictional limits, rather than those which applied at the commencement of the proceedings. However, much will depend on the content of any transitional provisions that apply to an alteration in the jurisdiction of the Local Court. If the transitional provisions do not apply the jurisdictional increase to pending proceedings, it is arguable that they are irrelevant to the prohibition against re-hearing: This point is the subject of conflicting decisions of the Local Court: Dear v Cassar (Local Court, Downing Centre, Cloran M, No 10491/02, 4 December 2002, unreported) (increased jurisdictional limit prohibits re-hearing); Fuller v Murphy (Local Court, Downing Centre, Lulham M, No 153767/00, 12 December 2003, unreported) (increased jurisdictional limit does not preclude rehearing).

If an order is made for a full rehearing, the award ceases to have effect and the proceedings are to be heard and determined in the referring court as if they had never been referred to an arbitrator.
If an order is made for a limited rehearing:
the award is suspended from the time the order is made until the proceedings are determined, and
the aspects ordered to be dealt with at the limited rehearing are to be heard and determined in the court concerned as if they had not been dealt with in the arbitration, and
following the rehearing, the court may reinstate the award with such modifications (if any) as the court thinks appropriate, and
the award, as reinstated, is final and conclusive, and is taken to be a judgment of the referring court.
Subject to this Division, this Act and the uniform rules apply to proceedings on a rehearing in the same way as they apply to any other civil proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 45] s 45 Discontinuance of rehearing (cf Act No 43 1983, section 18D)

leg:heading.title: Discontinuance of rehearing (cf Act No 43 1983, section 18D)

p.text: A rehearing may be discontinued, but only with the consent of all parties or by leave of the court.
If a rehearing is discontinued, the court is to reinstate the award from which the rehearing has arisen.
An award that is reinstated under this section:
is final and conclusive, and
is taken to be a judgment of the referring court, and

unless the court otherwise orders, is taken to have had effect as such a judgment as from the date on which it would have taken effect under section 40(b) had no application for a rehearing been made under this Division.
Under section 40(b) , the award would have taken effect at the expiry of 28 days after it was sent to all of the parties.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 46] s 46 Costs of rehearing (cf Act No 43 1983, section 18C)

leg:heading.title: Costs of rehearing (cf Act No 43 1983, section 18C)

p.text: A court that hears and determines proceedings on a full rehearing:
may make an order for costs in respect of the rehearing, and
may, in addition, make an order for costs in respect of the hearing under Division 2.
A court that hears and determines any aspect of proceedings on a limited rehearing:
may make an order for costs in respect of the rehearing as to that aspect, and
may, in addition, make an order for costs in respect of the hearing as to that aspect under Division 2.
This section applies to proceedings in respect of which a rehearing is discontinued under section 45 in the same way as it applies to proceedings that are heard and determined on a rehearing.

Referral to arbitration is intended to facilitate the resolution of the proceedings, and CPA s 56(3) obliges parties to assist that purpose by participating effectively in the arbitration process. As a consequence the conditional entitlement to rehearing should not be interpreted as justifying either party treating the arbitration process as a mere preliminary to a judicial hearing: Howard v Telstra Corp Ltd [2003] NSWCA 188; BC200303887 ; MacDougall v Curlevski (1996) 40 NSWLR 430; BC9605362 at (NSWLR) 433 per Priestley AP and 438 per Cole JA; Central Sydney Area Health Service v Cooper [2001] NSWCA 329; BC200105631 at [16] per Sheller JA. These propositions inform the exercise of the costs discretion conferred by the present section. It permits orders to be made both in relation to the rehearing and also in relation to the conduct of the arbitration. Despite the ordinary principle that costs follow the event (see UCPR r 42.1 ) costs may be ordered against a successful party on the rehearing because of their failure to adduce critical evidence during the arbitration proceedings: MacDougall v Curlevski (1996) 40 NSWLR 430; BC9605362 (indemnity costs ordered against defendants who succeeded on the rehearing after calling evidence not tendered in the arbitration proceedings); Quach v Mustafa (NSWCA, Kirby P, Sheller and Powell JJA, 15 June 1995, unreported, BC9504778) (costs ordered against defendants who obtained a more favourable judgment at the rehearing after using video surveillance film not tendered before the arbitrator); Morgan v Johnson (1998) 44 NSWLR 578; BC9804556 (modified costs order (each party bear their own costs of the rehearing) where plaintiff obtained a rehearing and obtained a less favourable judgment after defendant tendered surveillance film not tendered at the arbitration); Gambrill v Cook (1998) 44 NSWLR 578; [1998] NSWSC 367; BC9804556 (defendant entitled to rehearing costs despite calling additional witnesses at the rehearing, where their evidence had been known to the plaintiff prior to the arbitration. However a distinction is to be drawn between cases where the absence of evidence at the arbitration was the result of a deliberate forensic decision and cases in which the materiality of the evidence became apparent only as a result of, or after, the arbitration proceedings: Howard v Telstra Corp Ltd [2003] NSWCA 188; BC200303887 (arbitrator refused to accept plaintiff’s evidence in the absence of corroboration, corroborative evidence called at successful rehearing — plaintiff entitled to costs of rehearing, defendant entitled to costs of the arbitration); Sydney City Council v Geftlick [2006] NSWCA 280 (successful defendant ordered to pay costs of rehearing where a corroborative witness was not called at original arbitration). Furthermore, the exercise of the costs discretion does not rest on the general desirability of parties calling all their available evidence at the arbitration, it rests on the more precise factual investigation of whether a failure to do so has resulted in additional or avoidable expense in the way in which the proceedings have been conducted: Central Area Health Service v Cooper [2001] NSWCA 329; BC200105631 (defendant applied for rehearing on liability after calling no evidence on quantum at the arbitration, plaintiff applied for rehearing on all issues).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 47] s 47 Subpoena at rehearing against arbitrator (cf Act No 43 1983, section 18E)

leg:heading.title: Subpoena at rehearing against arbitrator (cf Act No 43 1983, section 18E)

p.text: A subpoena for the giving of evidence or the production of documents at a rehearing is not to be issued against the arbitrator to whom the proceedings concerned were referred just because the evidence or documents relate to the arbitration.
